author: ajsutton
content:
To be clear, for pectra OP Stack has already done the scrambling and prepped to make sure we‚Äôll be ready for the originally proposed mainnet dates. So given things shifted back a week we don‚Äôt need to increase the notice period for this particular fork. 

But I do think that as a general rule, it‚Äôs important to actually be code complete in clients with a stable spec before trying to set dates because downstream folk depend on that before we can really get busy testing and pulling in upstream changes to clients etc. Also it‚Äôs not great engineering practice to try and squeeze testing to make a date - that just reduces quality and increases risk. As many have pointed out, having a smaller scope and fixing that scope earlier is a much safer way to accelerate timelines and it delivers much greater results as it can shave months off instead of a week here or there.

author: ajsutton
content: And as mentioned above I think L1 should set an example for others in terms of the amount of notice given to users to allow them to exit if desired before an upgrade activates. I don‚Äôt mind what that timeline is exactly but we should line it up with things like the stage 2 definition for L2s and whatever other best practices there are for app platforms.

author: ajsutton
content:
I think both things can be true. In an ideal world pectra would already have shipped with a good long notice period. That would require changing something much earlier in the process - likely cutting scope or finalizing scope earlier. I‚Äôve been around enough to know that‚Äôs not easy and not always possible. I‚Äôm not asking to delay this release. OP stack doesn‚Äôt currently have a forced 30 day delay for upgrades so we can update quickly and it will all work out. 

Going forward there‚Äôs lots of pressure to keep moving towards stage 2 which does require long enforced upgrade delays. We can‚Äôt do that if L1 is shipping upgrades with a shorter notice period. We want to enable trust reducing features like long upgrade delays in lots of places through the ecosystem so we need to move L1 development towards better supporting it.

author: sky.cactus
content:
If there is an expectation that stuff built on Ethereum will need to change when Ethereum hard forks, then I feel like we have a pretty big problem as stuff deployed immutably to Ethereum should work indefinitely.

It is concerning that OP Stack will break because of a new transaction type.  I don't know why this would be the case, but it seems like L2s should be resilient to changes in L1 block shape and transaction types, as long as old transactions types remain supported.
